captions.text: (Applause)
Good evening.
My name is Vaishali.

It was right after 
my thirty-fourth birthday

that I was forced to take a career break 
for 18 months in my life.

I was a trailing spouse 
and I moved to Hong Kong.
I was nervous.

Incredibly nervous.
My nervousness

came not from the fact that 
I would have no source of income
but from the fact that
what was I supposed to do with my time
when I woke up in the morning,

when I didn't have a job 
to go to for the next 18 months?

And I need to rewind 
a little bit at this stage.

Like every typical Indian 
middle class family in the 1970s

I grew up in an intensely 
academic background
where success was:
getting good grades in school,
getting into a great college,

getting a good job, 
getting a big bonus,
getting a big increment.
Success was also finding a suitable boy

and getting married 
at the right time, yes.

And somewhere down the line 
the assumption was

that if you were successful 
in these two aspects of your life
you would find happiness.

We were raised to live life
in two dimensions.
You know, do not get me wrong

I'm not trying to mock 
the tried and tested theory in life.
All that I'm trying to ask you is that
what if you woke up one morning and found

either or both of these dimensions 
snatched away from you.
What would be your source of joy?
What would be your sense for?

It was about that time 
that I started my journey.
I was in Hong Kong.
I had a lot of free time at my hands,
so I said,

"You know what? 
This is the first time that
I actually have the time to think about
what I'm going to do with my time."
So, at that time I began my experiment.
And I tried cooking,
I took tennis classes,
I tried playing bridge,

every possible thing 
that the idle expat wife
could possibly do with her time.
But I failed.
I repeatedly failed.

I miserably failed at every activity 
I took up outside of my world.

It was possibly because 
I guess I wasn't enjoying it.
I didn't know it didn't make me happy.
So I said, "Ok, let me move on."
And it was that time of the year,
New Year's,
when most people wake up and say,
"You know what? This is it!"
"I'm gonna get fit."
"I'm gonna hit the gym."
"I'm gonna lose weight."
"I'm gonna look good."
So, I followed them all.
And the next thing I know is that
I'm at the gym

and I get this little instruction card 
from my trainer

which says, "1-2 kilometers 
on the treadmill six days a week."
I said, "Ok, I can do that."
So, I got on the treadmill,

put it on top speed or whatever 
it was supposed to be
and I started running.
And you know what?

I hated every single minute 
on that treadmill.
I didn't like it at all.

You know, like I'm doing this 
and I'm going nowhere.
That was a feeling I had.
And it was about that time that

a very dear friend of mine, 
Mokun Santana,

visited me in Hong Kong
for a marathon!

And, you know, a marathon is like 
the whole forty-two point two kilometers.
Yeah, that's what most crazy people run.
And what was funny was that

he had signed me up unknowingly 
for a ten kilometer race.
Yeah, the whole ten kilometers!

Now, if you've been following 
my story so far,

I came from a very 
non-athletic background.

I had precious little 
to do with the outdoors.

But I told my friend, 
"You know, Mokun,

you've signed me up, 
I don't want to let you down.

So, no matter what I'm going 
to run, walk, crawl if I have to,
but I am going to see you there,
at the finish line."
Come race day, I woke up bright and early,

really scared, as I made my way 
through the thousands of people

to kind of go towards the front
to start the race.

And I said, "This is possibly 
the most physically challenging thing
I have ever done in my life."

I haven't done anything besides 
using my brain
and my heart most of my life.

And I was going to try use my whole body 
to finish this ten kilometer race.
The gun shot went off,
and I slowly started my run.
Five hundred meters,
one kilometer,
two kilometers.

And I noticed that something 
really interesting
was beginning to happen here.

I was actually beginning 
to enjoy the feeling.

I felt like my heart rate 
was getting into the zone,
it was beginning to stabilize.
I was feeling happy. Insanely happy!

I felt calm, it felt peaceful, 
I felt different.

And before I could realize it,
I was standing
at the end of the ten kilometer race.

That's my picture with my buddy 
from ten years ago.

I found myself at the the end 
of that race thinking
for someone who has never even run
a hundred meter race in their life

to be standing there at the finish 
of a ten kilometer race
was simply beautiful.

And what's important is 
that I enjoyed every bit of it -

the sweat on my face, 
the dirt on my clothes,
the grime on my shoes.

And I felt for the first time in my life 
like a million bucks on the inside.

And it had nothing, 
absolutely nothing to do
with either my family or my work.

And a little voice immediately 
went off in my head, which said,

"You know what, Vaishali? 
Maybe you should do this again."

And so I did. 
Over the last ten years

I've run an excess of 
twenty thousand kilometers,
(Applause)

which is practically half-way 
around the equator

and across four continents 
and ten countries.
And I have proofs.
(Applause)

Now, you know, I kind of fell in love 
with the whole concept of running.

I felt like so far in my life 
I had been living in two dimensions -
work and family.
And I have found my third dimension.
It's like you are watching a movie
and you put on your 3d glasses,

and suddenly the whole world 
looks so different. It looks so good.
Finding your third dimension is important

because there are times
in your thirties, forties, fifties,
I don't know when,

but some time in your life 
you will come across this moment

when you feel dull, 
you feel jaded,

you feel cynical 
or simply overwhelmed

about what you're supposed to do 
with the problems you have in your life.

And your third dimension 
will be your ultimate faith healer,

restoring belief not only in yourself, 
but in life's possibilities.

Now, to find your third dimension 
you must take some time and reflect

on what are your truest moments of joy, 
and where did they come from.

It has to be a sphere outside 
of work and your family.

And if you come up with a blank, 
it's time to start your journey.

What the third dimension will do 
is it will make you resilient,
it will make you bounce back to work,

it will make you 
love your Monday mornings,

it will make you look forward 
to your weekends,

it will enrich the other 
two dimensions of your life.

So, sometimes in your life 
you will feel that you don't have control

over what's happening 
possibly at work or at home,
but your third dimension
you own, you control it.
It's yours forever.
So go find it!
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Discovering your 3rd dimension: Vaishali Kasture at TEDxNMIMSBangalore
